posts._title: Andrea Luka Zimmerman – Taskafa, Stories from the Street [+ Interview] (2013)
posts.title: Taskafa, Stories from the Street [+ Interview]
posts.excerpt: Structured around readings by renowned critic and essayist John Berger, TASKAFA (2013, 66 mins) offers a brilliantly incisive meditation on urban space and city life by investigating the complex history of Istanbul’s street dogs. Despite several major attempts by Istanbul’s rulers, politicians and planners over the last 400 years to erase them, the city’s street …

posts._title: Simon Lavoie – La petite fille qui aimait trop les allumettes AKA The Little Girl Who Was Too Fond of Matches (2017)
posts.title: La petite fille qui aimait trop les allumettes
posts.excerpt: Quote: The Little Girl Who Was Too Fond of Matches (orig French La petite fille qui aimait trop les allumettes) is a novel by Canadian novelist Gaétan Soucy. La petite fille qui aimait trop les allumettes was one of the novels chosen for inclusion in the French version of Canada Reads, broadcast on Radio-Canada in …
posts.titleEnglish: The Little Girl Who Was Too Fond of Matches

posts.title: Frost
posts.excerpt: Rokas and Inga, a couple of young Lithuanians, volunteer to drive a cargo van of humanitarian aid to Ukraine. When plans change and they find themselves left to their own devices, they cross the vast snowy lands of the Donbass region in search of allies and shelter, drifting into the lives of those affected by …

posts._title: Ingmar Bergman – Ansiktet AKA The Magician (1958)
posts.title: Ansiktet
posts.excerpt: When ‘Vogler’s Magnetic Health Theater’ comes to town, there’s bound to be a spectacle. Reading reports of a variety of supernatural disturbances at Vogler’s prior performances abroad, the leading townspeople (including the police chief and medical examiner) request that their troupe provide them a sample of their act, before allowing them public audiences. The scientific-minded …

posts.title: Napalm
posts.excerpt: We are living through a mini-boom in documentaries about North Korea. Film-makers are getting into Pyongyang to shoot – clandestinely, semi-clandestinely and on various pretexts – those vast statues and eerie cityscapes. Werner Herzog’s Into the Inferno suggested the North Koreans’ defensive mindset had something to do with living in the shadow of a volcano, …

posts._title: Émilie Brisavoine – Pauline s’arrache AKA Oh La La Pauline! (2015)
posts.title: Pauline s’arrache
posts.excerpt: Synopsis: It starts out like a fairy tale: there’s a queen, a king and their beautiful children, Pauline, Anaïs and Guillaume. But it’s a bit more complicated, a little more funky than that. Review: Emilie Brisavoine, who was discovered as an actress in independent films such as La bataille de Solférino [+] by Justine Triet …

posts.title: Chamber of Horrors
posts.excerpt: A one-handed madman (he lost the hand while escaping a hanging) uses various detachable devices as murder weapons to gain revenge on those he believes have wronged him.

posts.title: Les gommes
posts.excerpt: Les Gommes is an adaptation of the book written by Alain Robbe-Grillet in 1953 and published by Les Editions de Minuit.

posts._title: Slavoj Žižek – Moebius Strip, Crosscap, Klein Bottle: The Twisted Space of Subjectivity (2017)
posts.title: Moebius Strip, Crosscap, Klein Bottle: The Twisted Space of Subjectivity
posts.excerpt: A talk given at the “LACK II Conference on Psychoanalysis and Politics NOW” at Colorado College on Friday October 20th, 2017.

posts._title: Andrei Konchalovsky – Pervyy Uchitel AKA The First Teacher (1966)
posts.title: Pervyy Uchitel
posts.excerpt: From imdb:Soviet Union, near the Chinese border, 1923. A stranger has just come in this little country village. He is a teacher, sent by the Communist Party to teach the ignorant masses. But the countrymen are to help him, and even to let their children go and “sleep” at school instead of giving a hand. …
